questions.question: Identify which of the following is the correct formula for Mach number:
options: M = TAS / a
M = IAS / a
TAS = M / a
M = TAS Ã— a
questions.explanation: Mach number is defined as the ratio of true airspeed to local speed of sound (a).

questions.question: What is the result of a shock-induced separation of airflow occurring symmetrically near the wing root of a sweptwing aircraft?
options: A severe nose-down pitching moment or "tuck under".
A high-speed stall and sudden pitch up.
Severe porpoising.
Pitch-up.
questions.explanation: Loss of lift near the root moves the centre of pressure aft, producing Mach tuck (nose-down moment).

questions.question: Mach number is:
options: the ratio of the aircraft's TAS to the speed of sound at sea level.
the ratio of the aircraft's TAS to the speed of sound at the same atmospheric conditions.
the ratio of the aircraft's IAS to the speed of sound at the same atmospheric conditions.
the speed of sound.
questions.explanation: Mach is TAS divided by the local speed of sound at the prevailing temperature.

questions.question: For an aircraft climbing at a constant IAS the Mach number will:
options: increase.
decrease.
remain constant.
initially show an increase, then decrease.
questions.explanation: At constant IAS, TAS increases with altitude while the speed of sound decreases, so Mach number rises.

questions.question: The term 'transonic speed' for an aircraft means:
options: speeds where the airflow is completely subsonic.
speeds where the airflow is completely supersonic.
speeds where the airflow is partly subsonic and partly supersonic.
speeds between Mach 0.4 and Mach 1.0
questions.explanation: Transonic flight involves mixed subsonic and supersonic flow regions on the airframe.

questions.question: At Mach 0.8 a wing has supersonic flow between 20% chord and 60% chord. There will be a shock wave:
options: at 20% chord only.
at 20% chord and 60% chord.
at 60% chord only.
forward of 20% chord.
questions.explanation: Supersonic flow must decelerate back to subsonic via a shock near the aft boundary (around 60% chord).

questions.question: As air flows through a shock wave:
options: static pressure increases, density decreases, temperature increases.
static pressure increases, density increases, temperature increases.
static pressure decreases, density increases, temperature decreases.
static pressure decreases, density decreases, temperature decreases.
questions.explanation: Across a normal/compressive shock the flow decelerates, raising pressure, density, and temperature.

questions.question: For a wing section of given thickness, the critical Mach number:
options: will decrease if angle of attack is increased.
will increase if angle of attack is increased.
will not change with changes of angle of attack.
is only influenced by changes in temperature.
questions.explanation: Higher angle of attack raises local flow speeds and causes the wing to reach sonic flow at a lower Mach number.

questions.question: At speeds above the critical Mach number, the lift coefficient:
options: will start to increase.
will start to decrease.
will remain constant.
is directly proportional to the Mach number.
questions.explanation: Shock-induced separation reduces effective camber and lowers lift coefficient once Mach number exceeds Mcrit.

questions.question: As air flows through a shock wave:
options: its speed increases.
its speed decreases.
its speed remains the same.
it changes direction to flow parallel with the Mach cone.
questions.explanation: The flow slows abruptly to subsonic speed when passing through a shock.

questions.question: If an aeroplane accelerates above the critical Mach number, the first high Mach number characteristic it will usually experience is:
options: a nose-up pitch or "Shock Stall".
a violent and sustained oscillation in pitch (porpoising).
Dutch roll and/or spiral instability.
a nose-down pitching moment (Mach, or high speed tuck).
questions.explanation: The initial effect of shock formation near the wing root is a rearward movement of lift causing Mach tuck.

questions.question: High speed buffet is caused by:
options: the shock waves striking the tail.
the high speed airflow striking the leading edge of the wing.
wing flutter caused by the interaction of the bottom and top surface shock waves.
the airflow being detached by the shock wave and the turbulent flow striking the tail.
questions.explanation: Shock-induced separation produces turbulent wake that impinges on the tail, causing buffet.

questions.question: The "area rule" applied to high speed aircraft requires:
options: that the cross-sectional area shall be as small as possible.
that the variation of cross-sectional area along the length of the aircraft follows a smooth pattern.
that the maximum cross-sectional area of the fuselage should occur at the wing root.
that the fuselage and the wing area be of a ratio of 3:1.
questions.explanation: Area ruling smooths changes in cross-sectional area to minimise wave drag in transonic flight.

questions.question: An all moving tailplane is used in preference to elevators on high speed aircraft:
options: because the effect of the elevator is reversed above the critical Mach number.
because shock wave formation on the elevator causes excessive stick forces.
because shock wave formation ahead of the elevator causes separation and loss of elevator effectiveness.
because it would be physically impossible for a pilot to control the aircraft in pitch with a conventional tailplane and elevator configuration.
questions.explanation: Shock ahead of a conventional elevator can blank it, so a stabilator retains pitch authority at high Mach.

questions.question: Mach Trim is a device which:
options: moves the centre of gravity to maintain stable lateral stick forces in the transonic region.
automatically compensates for pitch changes while flying in the transonic speed region.
prevents the aircraft from exceeding its critical Mach number.
switches out the trim control to prevent damage in the transonic region.
questions.explanation: Mach trim applies automatic stabiliser adjustments to counter Mach tuck with increasing Mach number.

questions.question: What is the movement of the centre of pressure when the wing tips of a sweptwing aeroplane are shock-stalled first?
options: Outward and forward.
Inward and aft.
Outward and aft.
Inward and forward.
questions.explanation: Tip shock stall reduces outboard lift, shifting the centre of pressure inboard and aft along the swept wing.

questions.question: The airflow behind a normal shock wave will:
options: always be subsonic and in the same direction as the original airflow.
always be supersonic and in the same direction as the original airflow.
may be subsonic or supersonic.
always be subsonic and will be deflected from the direction of the original airflow.
questions.explanation: A normal shock reduces flow to subsonic speed without changing flow direction.

questions.question: As airflow passes through a normal shock wave, which of the following changes in static pressure (i), density (ii), and Mach number (iii) will occur?
options: (i) decrease (ii) increase (iii) < 1.0
(i) increase (ii) decrease (iii) < 1.0
(i) increase (ii) decrease (iii) > 1.0 or < 1.0
(i) increase (ii) increase (iii) < 1.0
questions.explanation: Across a normal shock, pressure and density increase while downstream Mach number is subsonic.

questions.question: An aerofoil travelling at supersonic speed will:
options: have its centre of pressure at 50% chord.
have its centre of pressure at 25% chord.
give a larger proportion of lift from the lower surface than from the upper surface, and have its centre of pressure at 50% chord.
give approximately equal lift from the upper and lower surfaces, and have its aerodynamic centre at 50% chord.
questions.explanation: For thin symmetric supersonic aerofoils, lift is roughly symmetrical with the aerodynamic centre near mid-chord.

questions.question: A bow wave is:
options: a shock wave which forms on the nose of the aircraft at MCRIT.
the shape formed when the shock waves on the upper and lower wing surface meet at the trailing edge.
a shock wave that forms immediately ahead of an aircraft which is travelling faster than the speed of sound.
the shape of a shock wave when viewed vertically.
questions.explanation: At supersonic speeds a detached bow shock forms ahead of blunt nose aircraft.

questions.question: When an aircraft is flying at supersonic speed, where will the area of influence of any pressure disturbance due to the presence of the aircraft be located?
options: Within the Mach Cone.
In front of the Mach Cone.
In front of the bow wave.
In front of the Mach Cone only when the speed exceeds Mach 1.0
questions.explanation: Pressure disturbances cannot travel ahead of the Mach cone; they are confined within it.

questions.question: The temperature of the airflow as it passes through an expansion wave:
options: increases.
decreases.
is inversely proportional to the square root of the Mach number.
remains the same.
questions.explanation: Expansion causes the gas to accelerate and cool, lowering static temperature.

questions.question: The influence of weight (wing loading) on the formation of shock waves is:
options: a higher wing loading will increase MCRIT
low wing loading will give a higher MCRIT
wing loading does not influence MCRIT.
wing loading and MCRIT are directly proportional.
questions.explanation: Lower wing loading requires less lift coefficient for the same speed, delaying sonic flow and raising critical Mach.

questions.question: What influence does an oblique shock wave have on the streamline pattern (i), variation of pressure (ii), temperature (iii), density (iv) and velocity (v)?
options: (i) parallel to surface (ii) increase (iii) increase (iv) increase (v) decrease
(i) normal to wave (ii) decrease (iii) decrease (iv) decrease (v) increase
(i) parallel to wave (ii) decrease (iii) decrease (iv) decrease (v) increase
(i) parallel to chord (ii) increase (iii) decrease (iv) increase (v) decrease
questions.explanation: The flow is deflected to follow the surface with increases in pressure, temperature, density and a reduction in velocity.

questions.question: Wave drag is caused by:
options: flying faster than MMO.
shock waves interfering with the smooth airflow into the engine intakes.
the conversion of mechanical energy into thermal energy by the shock wave.
flying faster than VMO.
questions.explanation: Shock waves dissipate kinetic energy as heat, manifesting as wave drag.

questions.question: What is the effect of a shock wave on control surface efficiency?
options: Increase in efficiency, due to increased velocity.
Increase in efficiency, due to the extra leverage caused by the shock wave.
Decrease in efficiency, due to the bow wave.
Loss of efficiency, due to control deflection no longer modifying the total flow over the wing.
questions.explanation: Shock-induced separation prevents the control surface from effectively changing circulation, reducing authority.

questions.question: At what speed does an oblique shock wave move over the earth surface?
options: Aircraft ground speed.
The TAS of the aircraft plus the wind speed.
The TAS of the aircraft less the wind speed.
The TAS relative to the speed of sound at sea level.
questions.explanation: The shock is attached to the aircraft; its footprint on the ground travels with the aircraft's ground track speed.
